subNodes.conversationText: root

Jarum and his companion were negotiating with one of their neighbors, a grumpy-looking loner, for a seat.

The loner obliged them but gave them a sour look. The young witch sat down.
[Continue.]
"I hope you didn't mind my speech. It seemed appropriate at the time."
"It's fine," said the young witch. "How are you?"

"Very good. I haven't been to the Bonnyjoy in three years. It's like old times. I mean to stay a spell. Res Ardor can wait. The road is long, and they don't even know I'm coming. You're here, and Adji's here, and --"
[Continue.]
"Forgive me! This is Adji, an old friend. We had no idea we'd see each other here. Adji, this is <FirstName>. I hardly know <him/her>, but I hope that changes."
"I see. Who is your companion?"
"Forgive me! This is Adji, an old friend. We had no idea we'd see each other here. Adji, this is <FirstName>. I hardly know <him/her>, but I hope that changes."
"A few rough folks?"

Jarum pointed to the table closest to the bar. About half of the people sitting there were young, and some wore scholars' robes and ribbons. Students, <FirstName> surmised. Mixed in with them were people of a different sort -- sinewy, older, weather-beaten, with hard, glinting eyes and shabby clothes.
[Continue.]
"Unlikely companions," Jarum observed. "I wonder what brought them all together."
[Continue.]

One of the students was carrying on boisterously with someone who looked every inch the ringleader of a brigand band. The other students looked uneasy, and some of their 'unlikely companions' whispered to one another like conspirators -- and perhaps were. <FirstName> turned back to Jarum, comprehending.
[Continue.]
"Are you going to introduce me to your partner in witchcraft, Jarum?"
[Continue.]
"Forgive me! This is Adji, an old friend. We had no idea we'd see each other here. Adji, this is <FirstName>. I hardly know <him/her>, but I hope that changes."
[Continue.]
"Pleased to meet you," said Adji.
[Continue.]

The three started talking, and soon Jarum and Adji were discussing all the places they'd been.

Adji looked young but had spent many years on the road. He had even been as far as Awadabyss. Jarum had been everywhere the young witch had heard of and many places <he/she> hadn't. He talked about the landscapes, the people, and the food intimately, and he relished informing the untraveled about them.
But <FirstName> had little interest in travelers' tales.
Sensing the young witch's boredom, Jarum ventured a different topic.
[Continue.]
He pointed to a couple seated across the room from them. "Before you came, they were kissing very enthusiastically."
[Continue.]
One of the people indicated was a rather ugly man in rich but tasteless clothes.
[Continue.]
His partner was younger. She had a pleasant, plump face and shrewd eyes.
[Continue.]
"Adji here was appalled."
[Continue.]
"Now you are making things up," said Adji. "You were appalled."
[Continue.]

"So I was. But I could tell that you were too, though for a different reason."

"I was appalled by their technique. They kissed like mudskippers, eyes bulging and mouths agape. You were appalled because they were making a spectacle of themselves. Ah! There they go again."
[Continue.]
It was true. The couple had embraced and were kissing. <FirstName> could not help thinking of Jarum's mudskipper comparison.
[Continue.]
Adji looked away.
[Continue.]
"Now here's a question," said Jarum, still studying them. "What makes them do it -- kiss like that, here and now? Why don't they just head to bed?"
"It feels good to them. I doubt they're thinking about it very much."

"But I find their desires confusing; indeed, I find all desire confusing. It's such a mixed bag. They desire the sensation of each other's lips and saliva, and they desire something beyond sensation -- the attention of a kindred spirit, perhaps. And yet they also desire the attention of the whole room! And though desiring the room's attention, they will nevertheless seek the privacy of the bedroom and sexual fulfillment -- eventually. They desire nakedness, and they desire to be clothed -- for clothed they remain."
"If they knew we were talking about them, I'm sure they'd stop."
"Maybe so, but that's not really an answer to my question."
[Continue.]
"It's not such a mystery. The preliminaries are as much fun as what they lead up to."
"You're right. And yet you talk as though this desire of theirs is their one underlying motivation."
[Continue.]

"But I find their desires confusing; indeed, I find all desire confusing. It's such a mixed bag. They desire the sensation of each other's lips and saliva, and they desire something beyond sensation -- the attention of a kindred spirit, perhaps. And yet they also desire the attention of the whole room! And though desiring the room's attention, they will nevertheless seek the privacy of the bedroom and sexual fulfillment -- eventually. They desire nakedness, and they desire to be clothed -- for clothed they remain."
[Continue.]
"Let's hope it stays that way."
[Continue.]

"To put it another way: they  have sexual, emotional, social, and merely sensual desires that kissing defers or gratifies. But it is not perfectly fulfilling in and of itself in any of these ways, and what comes later will not be perfectly fulfilling either."
[Continue.]
"Even if they had your technique?"
[Continue.]
"Are you flirting with me, Adji? But no. Not even if they had my technique. Nothing is perfectly gratifying, for them or for us."
[Continue.]
The woman glanced over and saw Jarum studying them. She whispered something to her companion, and their ardor cooled.
[Continue.]
"We've been caught."
[Continue.]
Adji and Jarum had friends in common, and they began discussing them. <FirstName> could have no interest in this conversation and excused <him/her>self.
[Continue.]
"If you happen by again, I'll likely still be here. Make sure I see you before your coven-binding. I have a little token for you, one witch to another."
[Continue.]
"A pleasure to meet you," added Adji.
[End.]
The young witch was naive about such things and had no opinion.

"But I find their desires confusing; indeed, I find all desire confusing. It's such a mixed bag. They desire the sensation of each other's lips and saliva, and they desire something beyond sensation -- the attention of a kindred spirit, perhaps. And yet they also desire the attention of the whole room! And though desiring the room's attention, they will nevertheless seek the privacy of the bedroom and sexual fulfillment -- eventually. They desire nakedness, and they desire to be clothed -- for clothed they remain."
The young witch preferred not to talk about it.

"But I find their desires confusing; indeed, I find all desire confusing. It's such a mixed bag. They desire the sensation of each other's lips and saliva, and they desire something beyond sensation -- the attention of a kindred spirit, perhaps. And yet they also desire the attention of the whole room! And though desiring the room's attention, they will nevertheless seek the privacy of the bedroom and sexual fulfillment -- eventually. They desire nakedness, and they desire to be clothed -- for clothed they remain."
<FirstName> listened, fascinated.

"Now the priestly class in Byssia believe, like we witches do, in the importance of threes. Three is a very holy number. We witches don't happen to think that, not exactly -- we don't put much stock in holiness or unholiness. But for the Byssian priesthood three is holy because they think it is the thing enabling all life."

"The sun and the moon are two, but where would they be without the sky, the third thing? Man and woman are two, but where would they be without flesh, the third thing?"

"You see how it is -- take any two things, any two of them, and you can find a third thing that's necessary for them. That is the basis of their whole theology; meanwhile, all priests (and only priests) are supposed to take two spouses."
"Do promiscuous people aspire to the priesthood, then?"
"Yes -- but that is true everywhere. Carnal delight is the source of every creed. Most people flirt and indulge their little desires; the rare few invent religions."
[Continue.]
"Speaking of carnal delights..."
[Continue.]
"How much time have you spent in Byssia?"

"Not enough! A beautiful, severe place; if you ever escape Eldest Lady's coven, you have to go there. The bluest waters you've ever seen, sunbaked cliffs above them. Ancient houses and temples that honeycomb the rock. Inland, the private groves of the Byssian dukes are as green as emeralds or the mounds of Praszkuzy. And its people are generous with food and drink and carnal delights..."

He trailed off, imagining distant scenes and distant companions.
[Continue.]
"Speaking of carnal delights..."
<FirstName> listened politely.

"Such a beautiful, severe place; if you ever escape Eldest Lady's coven, you have to go there. The bluest waters you've ever seen, sunbaked cliffs above them. Ancient houses and temples that honeycomb the rock. Inland, the private groves of the Byssian dukes are as green as emeralds or the mounds of Praszkuzy. And its people are generous with food and drink and carnal delights..."

He trailed off, imagining distant scenes and distant companions.
[Continue.]
Bored of Byssia, <FirstName> recurred to the 'rough folks" Jarum had mentioned earlier.

"Ah, yes." The older witch pointed to the table closest to the bar.

About half of the people sitting there were young, and some wore scholars' robes and ribbons. Students, <FirstName> surmised.

Mixed in with them were people of a different sort -- sinewy, older, weather-beaten, with hard, glinting eyes and shabby clothes.
Before the conversation went too far in this direction, <FirstName> asked Jarum about the 'rough folks' he'd mentioned.

"Ah, yes." The older witch pointed to the table closest to the bar.

About half of the people sitting there were young, and some wore scholars' robes and ribbons. Students, <FirstName> surmised.

Mixed in with them were people of a different sort -- sinewy, older, weather-beaten, with hard, glinting eyes and shabby clothes.
[Continue.]
"Unlikely companions," Jarum observed. "I wonder what brought them all together."
[Continue.]

One of the students was talking boisterously with someone who looked every inch the ringleader of a brigand band. The other students looked uneasy, and some of their 'unlikely companions' whispered to one another like conspirators -- and perhaps were.
[Continue.]
"It's very mysterious," Jarum continued. "Now, that man and woman are easier studies."
[Continue.]
He pointed to a couple seated across the room from them. "Before you came, they were kissing very enthusiastically."

"Ah, yes." The older witch pointed to the table closest to the bar. About half of the people sitting there were young, and some wore scholars' robes and ribbons. Students, <FirstName> surmised. Mixed in with them were people of a different sort -- sinewy, older, weather-beaten, with hard, glinting eyes and shabby clothes.
[Continue.]
"Unlikely companions," Jarum observed. "I wonder what brought them all together."
[Continue.]

One of the students was carrying on boisterously with someone who looked every inch the ringleader of a brigand band. The other students looked uneasy, and some of their 'unlikely companions' whispered to one another like conspirators -- and perhaps were. <FirstName> turned back to Jarum, comprehending.
"Well, I'm very forgiving," said <FirstName>.
Jarum laughed.
[Continue.]

"Very good. I haven't been to the Bonnyjoy in three years. It's like old times. I mean to stay a spell. Res Ardor can wait. The road is long, and they don't even know I'm coming. You're here, and Adji's here, and --"
